photos.description: Digitally analyzing stone trim along the house's southern elevation. The south paw is for scale. I could say that I carefully planned and framed this shot to create a hyperartistic chiaroscuro effect, but the fact is that I just had to put up with the dappling effect of the street trees behind me. In my final Robie photo, I'm departing from this series's main theme of brick geology to take a look at the second great exterior building material Frank Lloyd Wright used on this architectural tour de force. It's the Salem Limestone, known to builders as Bedford Stone or Indiana Limestone. And indeed it comes from the southern portion of the Hoosier State, where it has been quarried in such staggering quantities that it's a marvel there's any still attached to the Earth's crust. (But believe, me, there is.) The striking Roman Brick from the great production center of St. Louis, Missouri is visible, just barely, at bottom. But it's much better displayed in all its iron-flecked glory in Part 12, so I'll pass over it here. Much more vivid is the diagonal layering of the Salem. This is a classic sedimentary-rock structure known as crossbedding. It forms in dunes and ripples deposited and moved by flowing water or wind. For an example of it in a southern-Illinois sandstone outcrop, see this post. The reason this carbonate rock has crossbedding is that it's a biocalcarenite composed of tiny fossils and shell fragments. These came from marine creatures that lived in nearshore inlets, lagoons, and shoals some 340 Ma ago, during the Mississippian subperiod (Lower Carboniferous). The crossbedding often found in the Salem is one indicator that it formed in a high-energy environment of relatively shallow, agitated seawater. For much more on this site and 200 others in the Windy City, see my book Chicago in Stone and Clay, described at www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/9781501765063/chicago-i... And to see the other photos and descriptions of this series, pay a visit to my Geobrickology album.
photos.title: Geobrickology, Part 13: Light Splashed on an Ancient Shoal, the Frederick C. Robie House, Hyde Park Neighborhood, Chicago, Illinois, USA (1909)

photos.description:
Pamukkale, meaning "cotton castle" in Turkish, is a natural site in Denizli Province in southwestern Turkey. The area is famous for a carbonate mineral left by the flowing of thermal spring water.[1][2] It is located in Turkeys Inner Aegean region, in the River Menderes valley, which has a temperate climate for most of the year.

The ancient Greek city of Hierapolis was built on top of the travertine formation which is in total about 2,700 metres (8,860 ft) long, 600 m (1,970 ft) wide and 160 m (525 ft) high. It can be seen from the hills on the opposite side of the valley in the town of Denizli, 20 km away. This area has been drawing visitors to its thermal springs since the time of classical antiquity.[1] The Turkish name refers to the surface of the shimmering, snow-white limestone, shaped over millennia by calcite-rich springs.[2] Dripping slowly down the mountainside, mineral-rich waters collect in and cascade down the mineral terraces, into pools below.

Pamukkale sinter terraces
It was added as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1988 along with Hierapolis.

Geology

Travertine terrace formations
Pamukkale's terraces are made of travertine, a sedimentary rock deposited by mineral water from the hot springs.[1] In this area, there are 17 hot springs with temperatures ranging from 35 °C (95 °F) to 100 °C (212 °F). The water that emerges from the spring is transported 320 metres (1,050 ft) to the head of the travertine terraces and deposits calcium carbonate on a section 60 to 70 metres (200 to 230 ft) long covering an expanse of 24 metres (79 ft) to 30 metres (98 ft). When the water, supersaturated with calcium carbonate, reaches the surface, carbon dioxide de-gasses from it, and calcium carbonate is deposited. Calcium carbonate is deposited by the water as a soft gel which eventually crystallizes into travertine.

Archaeology
Travertine terraces at a hot spring at Pamukkale
There are only a few historical facts known about the origin of the city. No traces of the presence of Hittites or Persians have been found. The Phrygians built a temple, probably in the first half of the 7th century BC. This temple, originally used by the citizens of the nearby town of Laodicea, would later form the centre of Hierapolis.

Pools inside the archeological site
Hierapolis was founded as a thermal spa early in the 2nd century BC within the sphere of the Seleucid Empire. Antiochus the Great sent 2,000 Jewish families to Lydia and Phrygia from Babylon and Mesopotamia, later joined by more from Judea. The Jewish congregation grew in Hierapolis and has been estimated as high as 50,000 in 62 BC.[3] Hierapolis became a healing centre where doctors used the thermal springs as a treatment for their patients. The city began minting bronze coins in the 2nd century BC. These coins give the name Hieropolis. It remains unclear whether this name referred to the original temple (ἱερόν, hieron) or honoured Hiera, the wife of Telephus, son of Heracles and the Mysian princess Auge. This name eventually changed into Hierapolis ("holy city").[4] In 133 BC, when Attalus III died, he bequeathed his kingdom to Rome. Hierapolis thus became part of the Roman province of Asia. In AD 17, during the rule of Emperor Tiberius, a major earthquake destroyed the city.

Through the influence of the Christian Apostle Paul, a church was founded here while he was at Ephesus.[5] The Christian Apostle Philip spent the last years of his life here.[6] The town's Martyrium was alleged to have been built upon the spot where Philip was crucified in AD 80. His daughters were also said to have acted as prophetesses in the region.[7][8] During the 4th century, the Christians filled Pluto's Gate (a ploutonion) with stones, suggesting that Christianity had become the dominant religion and had begun displacing other faiths in the area. Originally a see of Phrygia Pacatiana,[9] the Byzantine Emperor Justinian raised the bishop of Hierapolis to the rank of metropolitan in 531. The Roman baths were transformed to a Christian basilica. During the Byzantine period, the city continued to flourish and also remained an important centre for Christianity. Wikipedia
photos.title: Pamukkale

photos.description:
There's actually quite a bit to this image, if you look at it long enough. First, for the Big Stuff: The Athabasca Glacier. According to Wikipedia, this glacier is "one of six principal 'toes' of the Columbia Icefield in Jasper National Park. It loses about 16 feet (5 meters) per year and has receded almost a mile (1.5 km) and has lost half of its volume in the past 125 years. That may seem slow to you in this age of climate change and global warming, and only a blip in the geological record, but it's still quite a bit and really hits home as one hikes the trail to the toe of this glacier, reading signs along the way of where the glacier toe *used* to be before receding.

If you look closely at this image, to the far left, you can see a line of tiny black dots. Those are people on a guided hike out onto the glacier. A guided hike is the only way you can actually stand on the glacier if you don't feel like taking a big ice bus loaded with people out onto the glacier. Other than that, you are prohibited from going solo onto the glacier, and with good reason. Along the way are hidden holes covered by glacial till (rocks and sediment) filled with freezing, rushing water that could suck you under. Then, once you are out on the glacier, unless you know what to look for, you could easily slip and fall into a hidden crevasse. Both of those would ruin an otherwise perfectly nice day because it's pretty cold up there, even in the summer. 

DYK the glacier makes it's own weather, including winds known as "katabatic winds" which blow down the glacier and towards the hiker. I can tell you for a fact that it was pretty darned cold on the day I hiked the trail.

See that rock in the foreground of this image? See the striations (lines) gouged into the rock? Those striations were created by the weight of, and suspended rocks in, the glacier. Weight and ice together ground scratches into the rock as the glacial ice moved forward then receded. You can tell the direction the glacier moved by these scratches.

Photographically, this single composition is composed of two focus-stacked images. One image was focused for the glacier and landscape in the background and the other image was focused for the striated rock in the foreground. That was really the only way to get a completely (or almost completely) focused image of the entire area, even using a wide angle lens, which is what I used on my Fujifilm GFX100s medium format camera. The 23mm lens is analogous to a 17mm lens on a 35mm camera.

photos.title: Striated Rock And Athabasca Glacier

photos.description: Facing northeastward toward the western elevation. Even relatively modest stone buildings are brimming over with geologic interest. For example, this oblique view shows the toll the process of weathering has exacted from ashlar (in this case, presumably the Upper Cretaceous Segovia Sandstone) subjected to the elements for nine centuries. In various spots on the church's exterior it's evident that the blocks' outer surfaces have fallen away. This may be a simple case of water soaking into the porous sedimentary rock and eventually breaking down its cement matrix. However, it may also signal the presence of case hardening, where solutions migrating through the rock have deposited minerals on the surface, and turned it hard and brittle. This comes at the expense of the inner portion, which becomes soft, crumbly, and very vulnerable to decay when finally exposed. Interestingly, much more recent Google Earth Street View imagery reveals that those weathered faces are still there. So apparently the Segovia Sandstone, even when degraded, changes little over the span of a single human lifetime—at least in this rather protected spot, hemmed in by other buildings. To see the other photos and descriptions in this series, visit my Architectural Geology: Spain album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Segovia, Spain, Part 24: Santissima Trinidad Church (12th Century AD)

photos.description: Taken along Great Lake Road, in the National Forest's Pond Pine Wilderness. This spot is about 10 mi (16 km) south-southwest of the town of Havelock. Occasionally I revisit photos I posted on Flickr quite a while ago and flesh out their descriptions, to the consternation of those visitors who can't tolerate anything longer than tweet-sized commentary. And then I add them if possible to a series I've established subsequently. Such was the case with this set's Part 14, which shows a nice stand of Pond Pine (Pinus serotina) growing in a special kind of Coastal Plain peatland known as a pocosin. This is pronounced puh-COE-zin, as I learned from a Croatan NF staffer. Before she diplomatically corrected me, I was trying to make it POCK-ah-sun, to rhyme with moccasin. Apparently this word, whether spoken correctly or not, derives from an Algonquian term for "wetland in a high place," or something similar. That's a good description, because pocosins are generally classified as one type of raised bog, with a subtly domed profile. This shot, like the one cited above, shows Pond Pines growing very happily indeed in the sandy, mucky Histosol (organic soil). The plants that inhabit this boggy substrate have adapted to unusually low-pH (acidic) conditions. The other photos and descriptions of this series can be found in my Botany of the Carolinas Coastal Plain album.
photos.title: Botany of the Carolinas Coastal Plain, Part 15: A Narrow Road through the Boggy Wilderness, Croatan National Forest, North Carolina, USA

photos.title: Geysir Strokkur - Iceland

photos.description: Taken along Catfish Lake Farm Road, about 7.4 mi (12 km) southeast of Pollocksville. The Gulf-Atlantic Coastal Plain is such a wonderful region for pine-spotting. This species, growing in the fascinating Southeastern type of peatland known as a pocosin, is Pond Pine, Pinus serotina. Many members of this much-beloved and much-utilized needle-leaved genus thrive in dry or rocky soils. But the P. serotina makes its home instead in this boggy wetland habitat, which is notable for its poor drainage and waterlogged Histosol (organic soil) with considerable sand content. It's a highly acidic environment. From what I've read, ecologists have further subdivided pocosins into specific categories. This one, I simply have to assume, is the Pond Pine Woodland association. It's characteristically found where the peatland has a slightly domed surface. As an old bogtrotter much more familiar with peatlands from Downeast Maine to the Indiana Dunes and Michigan's Upper Peninsula, this pocosin variant came as quite a revelation to me. More shots of this locale in Croatan follow. The other photos and descriptions of this series can be found in my Botany of the Carolinas Coastal Plain album.
photos.title: Botany of the Carolinas Coastal Plain, Part 14: Pines of a Pocosin, Croatan National Forest, North Carolina, USA

photos.description: Looking northeastward, at the church's southern and western elevations. It was a splendid early-spring day in this Upper Illinois River Valley town. What a lovely blue sky with cumulus fractus clouds. While by no means the Prairie State's most imposing house of worship, the Gothic-Revival First Presbyterian of Morris has a lot to commend it, geologically. To begin with, it was built fourteen years before Chicago's 1871 Great Fire (or actually its first Great Fire; there was also one in 1874). Due to a paucity of records, I'm not sure of the exact source of striking fieldstone that adorns this building's exterior. But I assume the builders did what their equivalents in other regional communities did, and harvested erratics (glacially transported boulders) from local farm fields. A lot of effort went into mounting those boulders. Almost certainly they were split and mounted rubble-style with their flat faces inward. However, their outward faces may have been worked, too. They have a rock-faced texture, but do not project out much, as do the stones at Chicago's Epworth United Methodist Church. What strikes my eye the most, though, is the high proportion of pink-to-red alkali-feldspar granites. Perhaps the masons preferentially selected them for their cheerful color. Or it may just be that the Wisconsin-stage ice sheet dumped a lot of them in this vicinity. However, the church's reddest erratics are rhyolite, the extrusive equivalent of granite. We'll take a closer look at them and many of their companions before long. To peruse the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Geology of Fieldstone & Cobblestone Buildings album.
photos.title: Geology of Fieldstone & Cobblestone Buildings, Part 17: First Presbyterian Church, Morris, Illinois, USA (1857)

photos.description: I've finally made it to the relative saftety of the sidewalk. Looking up Clark Street, at the building's northern half. For my current book-writing project, Chicago Suburbs in Stone and Clay, I've been reviewing for the umpteenth time the surprisingly abundant geologic literature on the sand-and-gravel spits that now form low ridges in the city, the North Shore, and Oak Park and Forest Park areas. This foray into spitology reminded me that North Clark and its unusual northwest-southeast trend is the result of its being the crest of the Graceland Spit. This landform, named for the graveyard I feature prominently in my Cemetery Science album, was built in the nearshore waters of Lake Chicago during its Nipissing phases, about 5.5 ka ago. In previous shots of this series, I've described the Northwestern Terra Cotta Company cladding, formed from Pennsylvanian (Upper Carboniferous) clays mined in the Illinois Basin, that adorns the lower portion of this storage warehouse. Here it is at much closer range. Of course the most eye-catching item is the olive-skinned representation of one of the original Reebie Brothers decked out as Ramses II. His sibling is an identical Ramses II, out of sight on the other side of the entrance. But the rest of the building's face is a nice assortment of botanical references, especially to Nymphaea lotus, the Egyptian Lotus. This aquatic plant was to the ancients a potent symbol of death and resurrection. Its flower buds emerge and rise above the waters of the Nile and open by day, then close and submerge again at night, and reemerge the following day. The Egyptian Lotus is present here both in closed-bud and opened-flower forms. And there are also palm-leaf motifs in the capitals of the squat columns. For more on this site, see my book Chicago in Stone and Clay, described at www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/9781501765063/chicago-i... To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Terra-Cottalogy album.
photos.title: The Geology of Terra-Cotta, Part 13: Detail of the Lower Facade, Reebie Storage Warehouse, Lincoln Park Neighborhood, Chicago, Illinois, USA (1922)

photos.description: Taken from the roof of the Natural Bridge, a little farther across the span than the Part 5 location. Here we're looking at the gap between the Bridge and the bluff. I especially like this shot because it shows a good uniformitarian process: water, that great and patient eroder, flows over the lip of the cliff. Year after year, decade after decade, century after century, little spring-freshet streams like this gradually widen what was once a narrow joint—a fracture in bedrock where no appreciative displacement has occurred between the two sides. And in this case, what was once part of the cliff eventually became a detached slice of rock, hollowed out below when the water hit a shale layer and had to move outward rather than farther downward. This water and rock are also the basis of all the green communities, algal films to tall-growing vascular plants, than live atop and on the sides of the exposed Pennsylvanian (Upper Carboniferous) Pounds Sandstone. Any geologist who is not also enraptured by the biota, and any biologist blind to the geology, are missing the essential fusion of things that makes all divisions of scientific study artificial constructions. For more on this beautiful and geologically fascinating locale, get a copy of my Geology Underfoot in Illinois. And to see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Natural History: Illinois album.
photos.title: The Bounty of Bell Smith Springs, Part 6: Terms of Separation, and Essential Connections; Bell Smith Springs, Shawnee National Forest, Illinois, USA

photos.description: To be more specific, the view is from the porch on the building's eastern side. Here there's plenty of what I take to be Regional Silurian Dolostone from Wauwatosa, or some other source near Milwaukee. But in this description I focus instead on the stout, polished column shafts. As I noted in Part 11, the shafts were fashioned from blocks of Montello Granite, an igneous intrusive rock with a mineralogical composition that is reputedly up to 40 percent quartz. This means that the effort it took to cut, shape, and polish this stone was much greater than it would have been to process competing granite varieties. One example of this: whereas a cutting wire works through about 4 ft (1.2 m) of normal granite per hour; the same device only makes it through 8 in (0.2 m) of the Montello in the same amount of time. Naturally, this drove up the latter's price—as did the fact that only about 10 percent of the rock extracted at the Montello, Wisconsin quarry was deemed suitable for architectural or monumental use. Classed as an alkali-feldspar granite, the Montello has been dated to about 1.75 Ga in the Paleoproterozoic era. This is interesting, given that that timeframe lies about 100 Ma after the Penokean Orogeny and about 50 Ma before the Yavapai Orogeny. Such crust-crunching, mountain-building events are thought to be a main source of granite-pluton production. But this sort of activity was noticeably absent in Wisconsin at 1.75 Ga. However, alkali-feldspar granites are thought to often originate in a different way, in extensional environments—where the crust is being pulled, thinned, and rifted. So perhaps that was the case when the bodies of magma that formed the Montello and associated extrusive rhyolites rose from the lower crust. One mechanism that causes such extension is called slab rollback. It occurs when subducting oceanic crust steepens its angle and causes the adjacent continental margin to stretch. To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit Architectural Geology: Southwestern Wisconsin album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Southwestern Wisconsin, Part 12: A View from the Porch, Green County Courthouse, Monroe, Wisconsin, USA (1891)

photos.description: Facing southwestward, from what was then a nice bed of hybrid tea roses toward the temple's eastern and northern elevations. Paestum's three splendid Doric temples are largely constructed with a rock type I informally call the Paestum Travertine. It should not be confused with the much more famous and much more widely utilized Tivoli Travertine quarried far to the north, in the Acque Albule region west of Rome (and found in some abundance even on modern buildings in my barbarian Trans-Atlantic region). The Paestum rock type, like the Tivoli, derives from a carbonate deposit formed from calcium-rich water. In this case, the water source was the nearby Capodifiume springs, which from the Pleistocene epoch to the present have apparently built out this site's surrounding coastal plain quite significantly. Another Quaternary-period building material found on the First Temple of Hera is a very young clastic rock, taken from Holocene dune ridges, which I identify as the Paestum Sandstone. It was used on the structure's upper portions, particularly the metopes. Both of these locally quarried selections are probably endemic to this archaeological site. But they certainly have withstood the test of time to a remarkable degree. Photos and descriptions of Hera's Second Temple, and of Athena's only one, will follow.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Paestum, Part 1: First Temple of Hera; Magna Graecia, Campania, Italy (ca. 550 BC)

photos.description: Looking at the central and eastern portions of the building's facade (southern elevation). I keep trying to put all of its design elements together in my mind as some sort of coherent whole, but can never quite make it. Still, from a geological standpoint, Old City Hall is certainly a fascinating farrago of different materials one can scrutinize as though they're their own separate entities floating free of one another. First, of course, is all that terrific, maroon-and-mottled rock. It's locally quarried Jacobsville Sandstone, which was deposited atop the great mafic lava outpourings of the Midcontinent Rift (MCR). The rifting event itself was possibly caused by a rare combination of two separate events: - Crustal thinning and extension caused by the separation of Laurentia (ancestral North America) from Amazonia, and - This part of Laurentia passing over a mantle plume. While the eruptive phase of the MCR is constrained quite nicely to ca. 1.1 Ga (Upper Mesoproterozoic era), it's not known for sure how long afterward the Jacobsville was deposited. Estimates have ranged from very late Mesoproterozoic to early Cambrian, an uncomfortably long span of about 500 Ma. Unfortunately this rock type lacks index fossils and other diagnostic features geochronologists rely on. The Jacobsville is complemented by a lot of lighter-toned Marquette Brick, another buillding material produced in this locale. I've discussed it a bit more fully in Part 21 of this set. And while I can find no proof of this yet, I'm guessing the porch's column shafts are Montello Granite, the red, quartz-saturated igneous rock from the town of that name in Wisconsin. It's also possible that it's the Peterhead variety of Scotland's Aberdeenshire Granite. But by the 1890s most courthouse and town-hall architects in the Upper Midwest were using the domestically produced Montello. Close-ups of the facade will follow. To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit The Brownstone Chronicles album.
photos.title: The Brownstone Chronicles, Part 22: Detail of Old City Hall, Marquette, Upper Peninsula of Michigan, USA (1894)

photos.description: Taken in the same spot, more or less, as the Part 9 locale, along the trail leading to the mouth of Boquillas Canyon. At this point it's clear that I suffer from Hechtexiomania, the condition of being too emotionally invested in Hechtia texensis. This member of the Pineapple Family (Bromeliaceae) has adapted itself to Big Bend's parched and infernal Chihuahuan Desert conditions. Wherever I found it in the park, I photographed it and marveled at its affinity for living in cracks and crevices of Cretaceous-limestone outcrops, as here. Unlike the plants shown in the previous shot, this individual was not in flower. But it does display the salient characteristics of its narrow, sharply toothed leaves. Those lower in the rosette are flushed deep red; the upper ones show the silvery scales that are, I assume, a moisture-retaining adaptation. While as noted in earlier descriptions I roundly dislike this species's common name, False Agave, I have to admit that the plant often does have a more regularly radial, agave-ish habit. But here the foliage is quite inrolled and contorted, to the point it almost seems to belong to a Tillandsia "air plant" instead. But, dagnabbit, H. texensis this specimen surely is. To see the other photos and descriptions in this set and my other Big Bend series, visit my my Natural History: Big Bend Region & All of Trans-Pecos Texas album.
photos.title: From Persimmon Gap to Boquillas Canyon, Part 10: One More Look at a Fascinating Species, Big Bend National Park, Texas, USA
SRs-1800 "Dolores", Kleczew

photos.description: Gazing westward toward the monumental, slot-in-the-hill entrance to this tholos, which is also known as the "Tomb of Agamemnon." Behold Bronze Age Building Skills at Their Boldest! Stonework on Steroids! Colossal Chunks of Conglomerate! Amazing Ashlar! Massive Masonry! Lovely Lithic Artistry! Petrologic Perfection! Now that I've gotten that disturbing alliterative outburst out of my system, let me identify the stone a little more precisely as the coarse-textured clastic sedimentary rock I informally call the Mycenae Conglomerate. Pliocene to Pleistocene in age, it was quarried on the floor of the Argos Graben nearby. It's also seen extensively in the walls of Mycenae's citadel, just 0.4 km (0.25 mi) to the northeast. I've come across various accounts of fancier stone types that were originally used to adorn this beehive tomb. I'll discuss one or two of them in the following photo's description. Here, however, it's worth noting that at least one reference mentions that the front exterior was clad in some sort of "marble" from the southern part of the Peloponnese. Whether this was the striking green Krokees Porphyry (known in Italian stonemason lingo as the "Porfido verde antico"), I'm not sure. Greece is so rich in nifty rock types that one has only to walk about fourteen paces from an outcrop of one variety to find yet another. To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Mycenaean Magic: Bronze-Age Stonework album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Mycenae, Part 24: Entrance to the "Treasury of Atreus," Peloponnese, Greece

photos.description: Looking eastward, so this is the western elevation. This site is situated in the Plaka, in a narrow defile on the northern flank of the Acropolis. Sources I've come across describe this church's subsequent modifications in less than admiring terms. And indeed, its facade seems to have been redone by the local equivalent of the Impromptu Fixit Company, employing a decidedly sloppy and randomized style quite alien to the meticulous artistry of Middle Byzantine masons. I'm not sure if all that rubble stone now adorning the front is the standard poros—marly Pliocene limestone quarried in Piraeus and Megara. But it looks as though the ashlar of the lovely and better-preserved Athenian-style dome is in fact the genuine article. Also preserved in the dome's drum is the standard cloisonné masonry technique, where the blocks of the pitted, fosiliferous carbonate rock are separated with thin red brick. And speaking of brick: there's all that characteristic archwork in that medium, too. To see the other photos and descriptions in this series, visit my Byzantine and Late Roman Worlds album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Byzantine Athens, Part 8: Transfiguration of the Saviour Church (early 11th century AD, with subsequent changes)

photos.description: Even at this closer range we can't really discern the subtle, fine-grained texture of the Permian-period Narragansett Pier Granite used throughout this lofty and ornate monument. But we do have a much finer view of the three allegorical female figures perched on its upper surfaces. When it comes to this ensemble of symbol-laden ladies, the old salt in me feels an instinctive preference for the one clutching an anchor. But of course the most dramatic of the bunch is the standing and more fully illuminated woman gesturing heavenward. Note the cross she carries in her left hand. It's festooned with Easter Lilies (Lilium longiflorum), plants that have long served as a Christian emblem of the Resurrection. The graveyard botany doesn't stop there, however. As noted in the previous photo of this set, the rich green foliage of a mature Red Oak (Quercus rubra) provides an effective backdrop. For more on the geologic origins of the Narragansett Pier, click the Part 14 link in the preceding paragraph. Subsequent close-ups of this stone will reveal its mineralogical makeup. To learn much more about this site and 200 others in the Windy City, make it your top personal priority to get a copy of my book Chicago in Stone and Clay, described at www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/9781501765063/chicago-i... And to peruse the other photos and descriptions in this series, pay a visit to my Cemetery Science album.

photos.description: Gazing down at the rocky debris on the floor of the intermittent Blue Creek, in Tuff Canyon. In the previous photo of this series I pointed out what I think is a lahar (volcanic mudflow) deposit in the canyon's lower wall. And I surmise that the detached chunk of stone shown here may have come from such a bed. I was once told by some instructor or fellow geologist that lahars can often be identified by a greater density of large rock fragments than is normally found in air falls found adjacent to them. This makes eminent sense to me, given the considerable hefting power of a mudflow coursing down a slope or stream channel. But in this case I stand ready to be corrected by anyone with a better grasp of igneous petrology and lithology than I. Alas, I was born in Illinois, not Iceland. At any rate, this boulder, whose true size is indicated by the Sharpie pen artfully placed atop it for scale, is worthy of a little scrutiny. Whether it originated in a lahar flow or not, there's no doubting that it's a breccia rather than a plain old conglomerate. This because its clasts (component rock fragments) are mostly angular rather than quite rounded. The darkest of its fragments are almost certainly Oligocene-epoch Bee Mountain Basalt, the unit also found cropping out at the base of the canyon cliffs. The gray to olive-weathering chunks may be another lava type, trachyandesite, or possibly ash-fall tuff. Some of the other, smaller rocks in this shot appear to be porphyritic specimens of various igneous types, with larger crystals (phenocrysts) set in a much finer groundmass. And there are some notable lumps of black and apparently aphanitic basalt. My other photos and descriptions in this series can be found in my Canyonlands album.
photos.title: In and About Tuff Canyon, Part 7: A Rock of Rocks, Big Bend National Park, Texas, USA

photos.description: Looking at one wee portion of the building's western elevation. At last I've made direct tactile contact with this famous Prairie School edifice. Architect Frank Lloyd Wright, who had a penchant for designing really snazzy Nineteen-Fifties houses in the Nineteen-Aughts, here chose a premium-quality building material manufactured to his exacting specifications, in what was then the Midwest's greatest brick production center: St. Louis, Missouri. In fact, FLW actually traveled to that great river city, no doubt at Mr. Robie's expense, to make sure he got exactly what he wanted. And what he wanted was long-and-low Roman Brick that measured 11-5/8 x 4 x 1-5/8 in (29.5 x 10.2 x 4.1 cm) and featured, in addition to its rich-red base color, copious silver-gray flecking. The latter was produced by firing the bricks at an especially high kiln temperature that encouraged their clay's iron content to migrate to the surface and congeal there. Clay for common-variety St. Louis Brick came from the city's abundant Pleistocene-epoch deposits of loess (windblown, glacially derived silt) that mantles the Mississippi River bluff. However, facing-quality brick such as the Robie's was made from the Cheltenham Clay, a Pennsylvanian-subperiod (Upper Carboniferous) coal-swamp underclay (paleosol, or ancient soil) mined in shafts under the city. Once this special consignment of Roman, St. Louis, iron-flecked bricks arrived on site, Wright directed his masons to lay them in two different mortars: - a normal buff-colored type for the horizontal joints, carefully raked out to enhance shadowing, and - a red mixture for the vertical joints that blended so well with the brick itself that even from a close distance the viewer sees not individual units of fired clay but continuous stripes, akin to the flat-lying sedimentary strata of northern Illinois and southern Wisconsin. The result of all is that the Robie House's profound sense of horizontality is intensified even more. For much more on this site and 200 others in the Windy City, see my book Chicago in Stone and Clay, described at www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/9781501765063/chicago-i... And to see the other photos and descriptions of this series, pay a visit to my Geobrickology album.
photos.title: Geobrickology, Part 12: Yipes! Stripes! at the Frederick C. Robie House, Hyde Park Neighborhood, Chicago, Illinois, USA (1909)

photos.description: Looking eastward at the main portal, situated at the northwestern corner of this church-turned-museum. As I noted in Part 21 of this series, I'm not sure whether this elaborately ornamented, Gothic-style pointed archway is a later add-on, but I assume it is, for reasons already discussed in the earlier description. At any rate, the amount of carved detail in what I take to be the Segovia Sandstone is impressive and fascinating to scrutinize. Regarding the angelic painting of the tympanum, I can't quite tell from modern imagery whether it's still there. To my untutored eye, its seraphim (?) fluttering about the Godhead certainly look Romanesque or Gothic, or at least Romanesque-ish or Gothic-ish. The Segovia Sandstone that gives San Juan and the city's later churches such a distinctive look dates to the waning phase of the Cretaceous period. Having just digested a hefty compendium of technical papers on the stratigraphy and tectonic history of Spain, I can say that this handsome golden-toned rock unit was deposited on the flank of the Iberian Peninsula's Central Range, which includes the nearby Guadarrama Mountains. The Central Range is largely composed of granitoid plutons injected into the upper crust during the end-of-the-Paleozoic Variscan Orogeny. This enduring igneous rock, including the Guadarrama Granite visible today in the Segovia Aqueduct, was subsequently uplifted during the next crust-compressing, mountain-building episode, the Alpine Orogeny, which began in the Upper Cretaceous. At about the same time, the Segovia Sandstone came into being as part of a transgressive sequence of shallow-water (intertidal to lagoonal) sedimentary strata deposited on a carbonate platform. These strata also included limestone and dolostone. To see the other photos and descriptions in this series, visit my Architectural Geology: Spain album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Segovia, Spain, Part 23: San Juan de los Caballeros Church (late 11th Century AD)

photos.description: Looking at one section of the facade (western elevation). In this final shot of the Dodge House, I've chosen one spot on the exterior that is quite representative of all of the cobblework. I'm not sure why, but I find the not-so-simple artfulness of the place mesmerizing. I think it's the combination of the stones, so carefully segregated by geologic type, and the little mortar boxes that hold them as though they're accessioned museum specimens lying in a cabinet tray. There are the black Mesoproterozoic basalts, emissaries from the cataclysmic Midcontinent Rift event; the even older pink and gray granitoids of North America's ancient core; the Silurian dolostones, at 425 Ma the youngsters of the lot. If you peer at these long enough, you'll sense that for all their implied tidiness there's actually a lot of tomfoolery going on. One sees this in the relentless regularity of various irregularities: in the differing thicknesses of dark, medium, and light bands, and in what angle the cobbles of each course are set. Any attempt to find a grand repeating pattern leads to madness. However meticulous the Dodges meant to be, they expressed something quite amazingly subconscious, a kind of architectural Ouija-board message in letters of stone. But to understand exactly what I mean by this, you really have to see the place for yourself. To peruse the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Geology of Fieldstone & Cobblestone Buildings album.
photos.title: Geology of Fieldstone & Cobblestone Buildings, Part 16: One More Close-up of the Edward Dodge House, Port Washington, Wisconsin, USA (1848)

photos.description: This shot, like Part 11, displays my lack of good sense in that it was taken in the middle of North Clark Street, a place where absentminded photographic pedestrians normally should not stand. While the viewer's eye is naturally drawn to all that sumptuous, Egyptianate terra-cotta on the ground floor (and in those snazzy window surrounds on the second level as well), I now focus on the much plainer upper facade. In future shots of this series I'll return to the Northwestern Terra Cotta Company artistry below—including the arrestingly olive-green pharaohs that flank the main entrance. The reason the stuff above is worthy of mention is that it is, unless I'm cruelly mistaken, white glazed or enameled brick. These types of glossy-coated bricking are venerable forms of architectural ornamentation in their own right. The glazed variety was used at least as far back as the ancient Babylonians (e. g., in their city's magnificent Ishtar Gate, of the sixth century BC). The enameled kind, on the other hand, was pioneered in the American Middle West by the Tiffany Company of Momence, Illinois. At first it was used primarily for interior hallways, bathrooms, and to provide highly reflective walls for office-building light wells. But then it caught on, at just about the beginning of the twentieth century, as decorative facade cladding, too. Whether the bricks here are enameled (with the outer coating agent fused by very high kiln heat into the brick itself) or just glazed (with an unfused coat that sits outside the brick), they're remarkably like architectural terra-cotta in their ability to be washed and maintained easily. Another bit of interest in the Reebie Warehouse's glazed or enameled bricks is that they're set in a pattern known as running bond. In this arrangement, one of the most frequently used by masons, all the bricks are set as stretchers (with their long sides exposed to view). And each stretcher of one course (row) is centered directly above the joint between two stretchers of the course directly below. In many other bonds, headers (short brick ends) also make an appearance in one way or another. But the running bond, as you can see here, is absolutely headerless. For more on this site, see my book Chicago in Stone and Clay, described at www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/9781501765063/chicago-i... To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Terra-Cottalogy album.
photos.title: The Geology of Terra-Cotta, Part 12: Still Closing in on the Reebie Storage Warehouse, Lincoln Park Neighborhood, Chicago, Illinois, USA (1922)

photos.description: From a tour guide's perspective, it's one thing to walk around the narrow roof of the Natural Bridge when all alone, and quite another to herd a gaggle of tour participants across it. Half of the group are birdwatchers obsessed with a chickadee on a distant tree branch; the others are the daredevil type too damned curious about what lies over the edge. A misdirected step and unintended nose-dive into the boulders below are all too imaginable. But then it's time for the guide to do some diaphragmatic breathing, and just relax. After all, everyone is enjoying the lovely spring day, and overtly grateful that you've brought them here. And besides, they've all signed waivers releasing you from personal liability. As it turns out, those waivers were probably not worth the paper they were printed on. Still, here you are years later, basking in the memory that you lost no one and killed no one and didn't even have a single sprained ankle on all of those trips to darken your name. And now, peering at this one moment frozen in time, you can turn your attention to an appreciation of nature shorn of all responsibility. You can meditate on the old fork-trunked ash tree, the same one shown from below in Part 1. Or you can ponder the moss-and-lichen-dappled Pounds Sandstone, which 320 Ma before had been a stream deposit in another, much earlier bedrock canyon. For more on this beautiful and geologically fascinating locale, get a copy of my Geology Underfoot in Illinois. And to see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Natural History: Illinois album.
photos.title: The Bounty of Bell Smith Springs, Part 5: High-Anxiety Time Atop the Natural Bridge, Bell Smith Springs, Shawnee National Forest, Illinois, USA

photos.description: Looking northwestward toward one section of the courthouse's eastern elevation. This portion of this Richardsonian Romanesque building reminds me powerfully of the arcaded porches of the original version of the Romanesque style, as articulated in the churches of Segovia, Spain. Here's one example of that. The three main exterior building materials, all products of Wisconsin, are visible in this shot, though the richly red Maiden Rock Brick here takes a back seat to the great mass of Regional Silurian Dolostone. Note the striking checkerboard of gaps and widely spaced ashlar blocks under the columns. This is what is known, believe it or not, as hit-or-miss masonry. It's much more commonly used in garden-wall brickwork, where the builders want some air and light to come through. There's actually nothing hit-or-miss about it; it requires quite some skill to get the pattern right. As I noted in the Part 10 description, I'm guessing that the buff-to-buttery-yellow ashlar is specifically Wauwatosa Dolostone, quarried in the Menomonee River Valley just west of Milwaukee. If it isn't, though, it comes from another locality in the eastern portion of the Badger State. And then there are those beautiful gleaming column shafts of Montello Granite. This intrusive igneous rock was a costly and premium-grade selection. Paleoproterozoic in age, it has an unusually high quartz content that made it devilishly difficult to cut, shape, and polish. But when all that extra effort was taken, the result was what may well be the most enduring of all building and monumental stones. To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit Architectural Geology: Southwestern Wisconsin album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Southwestern Wisconsin, Part 11: A Closer Look at the Green County Courthouse, Monroe, Wisconsin, USA (1891)
Łaba // Elbe

photos.description: Facing northward. Taken from the palace's entrance. Throughout this set showing this splendid building in its former ruinous state, I have made reference to a flock of free-range chickens who accompanied me on my exploration of this roofless hulk. Here, at long last, they make an appearance, pecking away in the middle ground. And to their left, there's also a free-range rooster perched on the lowest course of ashlar of the Blachernae Walls. He looks like a road-crew foreman, standing around idly and telling everyone else what to do. If you now visit the fully restored building, which serves as the Tekfur Sarayı Museum, you probably won't have fine feathered tour guides. But you'll still behold all that lovely Late Byzantine masonry, with its combination of locally quarried, Miocene Bakırköy Limestone and contrasting belt courses of red brick. To see it at its best, at least as I saw it half a century ago, take a look at Part 1. And I should also note that the column appearing as a dark silhouette in this frame still stands, along with one other. From more modern imagery I gather their shafts at least are handsome, veined Proconnesian Marble. That premium building material of the emperors and sultans was quarried on Marmara Island, in the Sea of Marmara, about 115 km (ca. 70 mi) to the southwest of here. The Proconnesian's protolith (original, unmetamorphosed rock type) was limestone laid down in the Precambrian or early Paleozoic era. Much later, it was transformed into its present form in the Permian period, during the Variscan Orogeny. For what it's worth, that far-ranging mountain-building event also triggered the emplacement of various bodies of granitic magma in what is now the northern part of the Mediterranean Basin— including that which ultimately supplied the Romans with the stone for the magnificent aqueduct in Segovia, Spain. While this concludes my various sets on buildings of Istanbul/Constantinople as seen on land, I'll later post some additional photos from the transits I made from the Dardanelles to the Black Sea, and back again. To see the other photos and descriptions in this series, visit my Architectural Geology: Turkey album.
photos.title: A Marvel of Masonry, Part 6: The Palace of the Porphyrogenitus (late 13th Century) and the Blachernae Walls (different sections in different centuries), Istanbul, Turkey

photos.description: Looking due east at the cathedral's facade (western elevation). Here St. Sava's three main, geologically derived exterior building materials are on full display: - The random-coursed, rock-faced, and variably toned Fond du Lac Dolostone, a relatively rare but fine member of the Regional Silurian Dolostone family. - The Mississippian-subperiod (Lower Carboniferous) Salem Limestone of the columns, arches and trim. Architects invariably call this minutely fossiliferous calcarenite "Bedford Stone" or "Indiana Limestone" instead. - The nicely patined copper of the dome roofs. What a classy combination. All the fancy sculptural detail and inscription work has been done in the Salem—one of this planet's most carvable rock types. But it is the Fond du Lac, quarried near the eponymous Wisconsin city, that gives this Byzantine Revival house of worship its striking texture and visual interest. This site, and many others in Milwaukee County, will be discussed at greater length in my forthcoming book Milwaukee in Stone and Clay (NIU Imprint of Cornell University Press, scheduled for release in early 2024). Stay tuned! And you'll find the other photos and descriptions of this series in my Glory of Silurian Dolostone album.
photos.title: The Glory of Regional Silurian Dolostone, Part 28: Detail of St. Sava Serbian Orthodox Cathedral, Lyons Park Neighborhood, Milwaukee, Wisconsin, USA (1958)

photos.description: Facing southwestward. In this, our final view from the Mycenaean citadel, most of the green and fertile floor of the Argos Graben is obscured in a rain haze made opalescent by the returning sunshine. Still, there's plenty to look at. Besides the foreground rocks of the battlement wall (Pliocene-to-Pleistocene Mycenae Conglomerate, Triassic-to-Jurassic Mycenae Limestone, or both), there's the exposed and very stony brown soil of the slope below and the wet and highly reflective surface of the archaeological site's access road. And just beyond the road, where there's that little curving hook of a driveway, is our final stop in this series. It's the so-called Treasury of Atreus, or the Tomb of Agamemnon, if you prefer to engage in some Schliemannesque romanticism (though that version of the name is not really credited to old Heinrich). In fact, it's a magnificent, rock-ribbed tholos tomb of an unknown person or persons. If you look closely, you can see the top of its long, narrow entrance marching most of the way up its small ridge. More on its splendid masonry in the concluding two photos in this set! To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Mycenaean Magic: Bronze-Age Stonework album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Mycenae, Part 23: Long-distance Tomb-gazing; Peloponnese, Greece

photos.description: Facing northeastward; the western elevation is to the left; the southern elevation to the right. What is all too corporeal in this frame is the flagrant soft-drink billboard, now blissfully absent. One can only wonder what the eleventh-century mind (or palate) would have made of that splendid product. But I'll refrain from any reveries on the jarring juxtaposition here of medieval and modern, the sacred and the profane, and so on. While it may lack some of the architectural fine points of its near-contemporaries, the Sts. Theodores Church and the Daphni Monastery, Incorporeal Angels is an absolute sweet pea illustrating with admirable simplicity Middle Byzantine masonry techniques and materials at least as well as any other site in Attica. Once again, the ashlar appears to be the soft, pitted, fossiliferous poros of Pliocene age. It's a marly limestone quarried in such locales as Megara and Piraeus. And then again there's the cloisonné technique of placing very thin bricks as spacers between the stone blocks. And the typical brick arches, and the terra-cotta roofing tiles, with the arched kalupter sections alternating with the flat solenes pieces. To see the other photos and descriptions in this series, visit my Byzantine and Late Roman Worlds album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Byzantine Athens, Part 7: Incorporeal Angels Church (late 11th century AD, with subsequent rebuilding and restoration)

photos.description: Facing westward. Allegorical female figures were a standard trope of the Victorian-era monumental trade, and practically every American cemetery of a certain size and age has its share of these classically garbed ladies grieving, symbolizing birth and motherhood, representing one profession or another, pointing heavenward, or pensively pondering eternity, The Hoyt Monument is notable because it sports a whole trio of such figures, nicely framed at this time of year by the spreading crown of a native Red Oak (Quercus rubra). As succeeding close-ups will demonstrate, all of these sculptures and their accompanying ornamerntation look as clean-edged and unweathered as they day they were carved 140 years ago. Why? Well, for one thing, they're made of one of the greatest and most enduring of American monumental stones, the Narragansett Pier Granite. Quarried in the lovely Rhode Island town of Westerly, which I featured for botanical reasons in my Plant Explorer's Guide to New England, the Narragansett Pier is a fine- and tight-grained intrusive igneous rock marketed unsurprisingly as "Westerly Granite." The specific variety used here was "Blue Westerly." (Stone-trade people are forever hyping pale-gray rock types as being blue, especially those that are not warm-toned enough to be buff or slightly pink.) Permian in age, the Narragansett Pier formed in masses of magma injected into the upper crust during the latter part of Alleghenian Orogeny and the assembly of the Pangaean supercontinent, when crustal compression was replaced by shearing due to the counterclockwise rotation of southeastern New England. It is widely represented in Graceland, Rosehill, Forest Home, and other Chicago and Milwaukee cemeteries. During the heyday of its production (now sadly ceased), this tough and reliasble stone was a major competitor of Vermont's Barre Granodiorite. Unfortunately, the very qualities that make the Narragansett Pier such a durable selection also make it a trifle boring. It lacks the more striking textures and ruddy tones of Wisconsin's Waupaca, Wausau, and Montello alkali-feldspar granites. Or, for that matter, the pleasing salt-and-pepper aspect of the Barre. Still, it has been a remarkable performer in a brutal continental climate that ofttimes plays havoc with such weak-sister varieties as the Shelburne and Carrara Marbles, and the Salem Limestone. To learn much more about this site and 200 others in the Windy City, make it your top personal priority to get a copy of my book Chicago in Stone and Clay, described at www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/9781501765063/chicago-i... And to peruse the other photos and descriptions in this series, pay a visit to my Cemetery Science album.
photos.title: Graveyard Geology of Chicago, Part 14: William M. Hoyt Monument, Graceland Cemetery, Uptown Neighborhood (1883)

photos.description: This photo is a sort of supplement to this set's Part 3, which shows large chunks of basalt that went flying through the air back in the Oligocene epoch. That was during one of many volcanic eruptions that occurred in Trans-Pecos Texas and adjoining Mexico and New Mexico in that infernal episode of prehistory. Such big rocks, now embedded in the pyroclastic deposits exposed on Tuff Canyon's walls, are called ballistic blocks, no doubt because of the trajectories they described during their brief airborne phase. Ballistic blocks can be distinguished from other big stone fragments carried directly along within pyroclastic flows by the impact sag zones located under them. I think I'm seeing one of those depressions under the bigger black boulder in this image, but it may be wishful thinking. At any rate, this big chunk of Bee Mountain Basalt seems to be sitting in a coarse-textured bed more characteristic of a lahar (water-lubricated debris flow) than of a pyroclastic surge or flow. Lahar deposits definitely exist at this site, and I'll show another example of one in a photo to follow. Regardless of whether this shot shows true ballistic blocks or not, the fact remains that there are quite a few others nearby that unequivocaly are. As I walked about during my visit here and saw how many of these lithic projectiles are visible in this relatively small cross-section of the volcanic material that blankets this locale, I became morbidly fascinated with what it must have been like to actually be on the receiving end of this hailstorm from hell. Years before, I'd been on one active volcano (Stromboli) where globs of lava and hot rock were falling nearby, and on one other (Etna) where the same had happened a day or two before I got there, and there were freshly minted volcanic bombs lying around everywhere. But the eruption that hefted Tuff Canyon's arsenal of mafic missiles would have been orders of magnitude more powerful. After poring over this photo for quite a while, I'd like to think that its two boulders are indeed ballistic blocks that landed ker-splat into a still-viscous lahar. Either that, or they landed first and were then glommed over and buried by that rocky glop. My other photos and descriptions in this series can be found in my Canyonlands album.
photos.title: In and About Tuff Canyon, Part 6: My Morbid Fascination with Flying Boulders, Big Bend National Park, Texas, USA

photos.description: Looking at a portion of the southern elevation. Here the basic building blocks that Frank Lloyd Wright used to create the Robie's powerful sense of horizontality are on full view. To get a better sense of their overall impact, see Part 9 of this set. In this shot, however, we can best comprehend the stratigraphic sandwich that the house really is. Those deep-set square windows notwithstanding, the components of primary interest are the red, iron-flecked Roman Brick manufactured in St. Louis, Missouri, and the paler and more pedestrian Salem Limestone that flanks it. The Salem, which just happens to be the most commonly encountered architectural rock type in the US, is much better known in the quarrying and building trades as Bedford Stone or Indiana Limestone. As I say in Chicago in Stone and Clay: Once the urban explorer learns to recognize the Salem, it’s a constant companion through life, at least if one stays in America. In the heart of every city, in each of its suburbs, in one-stop-sign towns halfway to Santa Fe, there is always some of this utterly unassuming stone lurking. It’s in the official face of the shoebox post office, on the Gothic ramparts of the local high school, in the lintels and window trim of the side-street Methodist church. And it's on some of the most architecturally distinguished buildings, too. Dating to the Mississippian subperiod (Lower Carboniferous), the Salem may seem unremittingly bland at a distance, but closer up it often reveals fascinating details. I'll address these in another close-up to follow. At this range, what I noted in Part 10 about Wright's clever manipulation of mortar—white in the horizontal joints and red in the vertical, to accentuate the sense of unbroken strata—is more apparent. The one beef I have with Wright's Robie's design is that he, like many a heedless architect before and after him, allowed the Salem to extend down to grade. Often, when it comes into contact with the ground, and especially sidewalks, this porous rock will absorb meltwater and its dissolved deicer salts. The latter can wreak havock later on, in the form of efflorescence crusts and the case-hardening and breakdown of the rock itself. But in this spot at least FLW's luck seems to have held. The only noticeable change to the stone's surface, besides a few scuffs, is the growth of some calciphilic algae. For much more on this site and 200 others in the Windy City, see my book Chicago in Stone and Clay, described at www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/9781501765063/chicago-i... And to see the other photos and descriptions of this series, pay a visit to my Geobrickology album.
photos.title: Geobrickology, Part 11: Close-up of the Frederick C. Robie House, Hyde Park Neighborhood, Chicago, Illinois, USA (1909)

photos.description: Looking basically eastward, at this former church's southern elevation and bell tower. What I take to be this building's main exterior material, the Late Cretaceous Segovia Sandstone, is complemented in the upper tier of tower windows with red brick of unknown date. In those rather non-Romanesque ogee arches that brick seems to be present in quite a range of sizes, and is quite reminiscent of ancient Roman brickwork used in the same capacity. One aspect of this photo that puzzles me a bit is the quite uniform white band atop the blue portion of the sky. It may be the straightest-edged bottom of a cloud I've ever seen. Or perhaps it's just a zone of the original slide that faded with remarkable uniformity. But if so, why was the tower's weathervane protruding into the white layer unaffected? In my final shot of San Juan, which will follow, I'll focus on the larger significance of the time in which the Segovia Sandstone was deposited. To see the other photos and descriptions in this series, visit my Architectural Geology: Spain album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Segovia, Spain, Part 22: San Juan de los Caballeros Church (late 11th Century AD)

photos.description: This is one of the most interesting mineral water sources, situated near the  Nuskova village. The hole to mineral water was drilled already some 60 years ago, but local people were using water even much before. Water is heavily mineralized, intense red colour reveals big quantities of iron. So, it's advised to drink it only in smaller quantities.
photos.title: Slatinski vrelec

photos.description: The just-approved cover of my next book, which is scheduled for release in early (probably March or April) 2024. I'm both relieved and delighted to note that I am now done with the proofs and the indexing. Whew. Now off to the printer! I'll post an update when it's available. This guide, the younger sibling of Chicago in Stone and Clay, continues the series with an in-depth look at the geologic origins and significance of building stone, terra-cotta, and brick—especially the famous Cream City Brick—adorning 129 sites in Milwaukee County. Cover design by David Baldeosingh Rotstein. Upper photo © f11photo / shutterstock.com; inset photos by me. And speaking of the inset photos, they show three of Milwaukee's more frequently encountered building materials. From top to bottom: - Wauwatosa Dolostone (Silurian); - Cream City Brick (base clay from local Quaternary fluviatile, lacustrine, and glacial deposits); and - Wausau Granite (Paleoproterozoic).
photos.title: Milwaukee in Stone and Clay: A Guide to the Cream City's Architectural Geology (NIU Imprint of Cornell University Press)

photos.description: Looking at the southern side of the southwestern corner. For a good overall view of this elevation, see Part 13. It's obvious that Elizabeth and Edward Dodge were both artful and geologically astute when they arranged these Lake Michigan cobbles in their fancily ridged lime mortar. But first, the quoin ashlar. It's highly fosssiliferous and reefal Regional Silurian Dolostone, most likely from a quarry a few miles away in Knellsville, Grafton, or Cedarburg. Visible here are shell molds and casts of brachiopods, bivalves, or both, and probably other invertebrate marine critters are represented as well. This rock type formed on the edge of the developing crustal downwarp known as the Michigan Basin, in shallow, subtropical saltwater. This was at a time when this part of Laurentia, North America's Proterozoic-to-Early-Paleozoic predecessor, was situated about 30 degrees south of the equator (in contrast to its current position, 43 degrees North). As far as the cobbles go, the Dodges lined them up, in what appears at this scale to be an attractive but noncyclical way, as follows: - BLACK: mostly Late Mesoproterozoic basalts erupted during the Midcontinent Rift event about 1.1 Ga ago; probably from Upper Michigan's Keweenaw Peninsula. Also some gabbro from the same time and area, or a very dark-gray granitoid from the Canadian Shield. - GRAY OR PINK, AND SPECKLED: Paleoproterozoic to Archean granitoids from the Canadian Shield. Northern Wisconsin, Upper Michigan, or Ontario. - BONE-WHITE TO BUFF: More Regional Silurian Dolostone, from a more northern locale in eastern Wisconsin or Upper Michigan. Some of it seems reefal; some, interreefal and devoid of fossils. (On second glance, I do also see a mold of a narrow-conic snail shell. I'll have to look up its genus.) All of these rocks were first transported south from their outcrop locations by a Wisconsin-stage ice sheet late in the Pleistocene ice age. Then they were jostled, caressed, and tumbled into more ovoid or spheroidal forms by the lake surf. To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Geology of Fieldstone & Cobblestone Buildings album.
photos.title: Geology of Fieldstone & Cobblestone Buildings, Part 15: Close-up of the Edward Dodge House, Port Washington, Wisconsin, USA (1848)

photos.description: Taken, for some fool reason, in the middle of Clark Street. This is one of the North Side's busiest thoroughfares, and I'm probably lucky I wasn't run over, or at least the subject of some furious ankhing. At this range some of the details of the lower facade's Egyptianate motifs are more apparent. Up above the stout columns are scarab medallions and powder-blue and brick-red winged emblems of Amon Ra, god of the noonday sun. All this and the white, coursed cladding were produced by the artisans of the Northwestern Terra Cotta Company. That famous firm was situated about twenty blocks west of here, on the near bank of the Chicago River's North Branch. While the manufacturers of the city's Chicago Common Brick usually relied on the clays of local glacial-till deposits, Northwestern needed higher-grade base material free of pebbles and other impurities. Consequently, it depended on large quantities of Pennsylvanian (Upper Carboniferous) underclays and marine shales shipped in by rail from Illinois Basin coal mines. To the miners themselves, the underclays were just a waste product; to the Northwestern crew, the stuff of high art. But to geologists and paleontologists, they're something else again—the paleosols or ancient soils in which the giant free-sporing scale trees of Pangaean swamp forests had grown some 300 Ma ago. For more on this site, see my book Chicago in Stone and Clay, described at www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/9781501765063/chicago-i... To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Terra-Cottalogy album.
photos.title: The Geology of Terra-Cotta, Part 11: Closing in on the Reebie Storage Warehouse, Lincoln Park Neighborhood, Chicago, Illinois, USA (1922)

photos.description: Taken on a lovely, sunlit, early-April day, when the leaf buds were just beginning to break. The last I checked, there were two ways to get onto the top of the Natural Bridge: -the direct method involving a set of ancient-looking and in some cases disconcertingly loosely anchored metal ladder rungs on the vertical face of the Pounds Sandstone; and - a much more circuitous route via a footpath that mounts the bluff more gradually some distance away. When I've led tour groups here, the latter approach has really been the only option, given that some participants are hardly orangutans in the brachiation department. And the longer, more leisurely stroll also gives everyone a chance to see the canyon's various botanical wonders. One of these wonders is the "lichen gardens" (Cladonia spp. primarily), that have established themselves all over the place in the thin, sandy, clifftop substrate. Some of these mini-ecosystems can be spotted in the background, as the very-light-green patches under the trees on the far side of the stone ramp. Note that even the ramp itself hosts quite a selection of lichen, moss, and algal communities. And looking down at the visible portion of the Bridge's vertical face, it's possible to see some thin crossbeds exposed in this Lower Pennsylvanian (Upper Carboniferous), fluvially deposited sandstone. For a better look at this characteristic sedimentary feature in the Pounds, see Part 3 of this set. While we're at it, we might as well be a trifle dendrological, as well. The large tree with the exfoliating bark to the left is an American Sycamore (Platanus occidentalis). This, our native plane species, can grow to beastly sizes in the Land of Lincoln—especially in bottomlands along the Illinois and Wabash Rivers. For more on this beautiful and geologically fascinating locale, get a copy of my Geology Underfoot in Illinois. And to see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Natural History: Illinois album.
photos.title: The Bounty of Bell Smith Springs, Part 4: Detail of the Upper Surface of the Natural Bridge, Bell Smith Springs, Shawnee National Forest, Illinois, USA

photos.title: 2023-08-17-20h30m08s221B

photos.description:
The narrow color stripes that extend over long distances make Chinle formation one of the most interesting in the Grand Staircase.

Chinle mudstone is often very friable and crumbly. If you step on it, it leaves a deep boot print. Avoid walking on it, therefore, and just photograph it from solid ground.
photos.title: Natural tapestry: Chinle stripes detail

photos.description: Once again we're facing eastward, but this time we're looking at closer range, at the lower portion of the western elevation. Of the exterior building materials on view here, two are fully documented. And the third, the pale-buff, rock-faced ashlar, can be identified in a general sort of way with a high degree of confidence. It's almost certainly Regional Silurian Dolostone (RSD) from the eastern side of Wisconsin. My guess is that it is specifically the RSD variety I call the Wauwatosa Dolostone, quarried in the Menomonee River Valley just west of Milwaukee. I know it was definitely used for one of the campus halls of Beloit College, not that far from here. However, rock virtually indistinguishable from this was also produced in other communities in the greater Cream City area. In any event, this close carbonate cousin of true limestone was deposited some 425 Ma ago in shallow, reef-studded waters on the western fringe of the great crustal downwarp known as the Michigan Basin. On this exterior, the Wauwatosa (or whatever) provides a dramatic contrast to the ruddier tones of the Maiden Rock Brick and the Paleoproterozoic-era Montello Granite of the pillar shafts. For more on the geology and Badger State origins of these two, check out Part 9 of this set, and also stay tuned for more close-ups and descriptions. To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit Architectural Geology: Southwestern Wisconsin album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Southwestern Wisconsin, Part 10: Detail of the Green County Courthouse, Monroe, Wisconsin, USA (1891)

photos.description: Thor's Well is a geologic feature at Cape Perpetua on the Oregon coast.  The well is the result of the collapse of the roof of a sea cave.  It is approximately 18 feet wide and 20 feet deep.  The dog accompanying the man taking shots of the well has had enough!  I didn't go down to the edge as I am clumsy enough on flat ground, much less on uneven, slippery basalt with waves surging around. Plus, the spray is intense.  I value my life and my cameras more than the excitement of getting close.
photos.title: Thor's Well

photos.description: Taken inside what was then the hollowed-out shell of the Palace. I want to think this was what remained of its western wall, but I'm not sure. As forlorn and even postapocalyptic as this photo seems, it shows more detail of the building's once-beautiful masonry. Obviously there have been modifications and patching with newer ashlar blocks over the centuries, but at the very least the older stuff is the Miocene-epoch Bakırköy Limestone. And some of the original red-brick belt coursing is still there, too. I'd love to find out if the surviving timber beam remnants so prominently visible here were original as well. And what tree species were they cut from? I could speculate that they were some sort of native oak, but idle speculation is often worse than worthless. I'll continue to investigate. To see the other photos and descriptions in this series, visit my Architectural Geology: Turkey album.
photos.title: A Marvel of Masonry, Part 5: The Palace of the Porphyrogenitus (late 13th Century) and the Blachernae Walls (different sections in different centuries), Istanbul, Turkey
Shake hole NW of Glyntawe Sept 2023

photos.description: Facing northeastward at the building's facade (southern elevation) as well as its western side. An arresting mélange of three not always reconcilable architectural styles—Richardsonian Romanesque, Second Empire, and Renaissance Revival—Old City Hall as restored is quite the colorful Yooper showboat. (And in case you don't already know, Yooper = a resident of the UP = the Upper Peninsula.) Given its maroons and reds and pinks, it should by rights be the City Hall of Helium, Mars, and one could easily imagine Dejah Thoris and John Carter striking a pose in front of its main entrance. But then the redness fits here, too, because Marquette was one of North America's great brownstone production centers when this edifice was erected. It always warms the cockles of my heart when I learn that a community's elders or its vox populi insisted on their new municipal building being made of local materials. And such was the case here. While I don't know the story behind the roofing tiles, I've discovered that the ashlar, the Jacobsville Sandstone variety of Lake Superior Brownstone, was extracted just south of town, in what seems to have been Marquette's main quarrying district. The other main building material, which I henceforth christen Marquette Brick, was also manufactured nearby. I need to find out what its source material was—glacial till? some hematite-rich shale deposited along with the Jacobsville atop the lava flows of the Midcontinent Rift? So far this is my one documented use of this brick type, though I'm sure there are various others. The Marquette brand of the Jacobsville, on the other hand, was definitely exported far and wide, and in this photo set I've described and will continue to describe its uses in other cities. For example, here. And close-ups of this particular site will also follow. To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit The Brownstone Chronicles album.
photos.title: The Brownstone Chronicles, Part 21: Old City Hall, Marquette, Upper Peninsula of Michigan, USA (1894)

photos.description: Taken near the end of our track, along the Boquillas Canyon Trail. We are on high ground, not far from the trailhead parking lot, and we're looking south-southwestward. Before entering the vertiginous, awe-inspiring landscape of Boquillas Canyon proper, it's only fitting that we take a look at the twists and turns of the Rio Grande a bit upstream, in less dramatic terrain. Besides the point bars and the floodplain plant communities there are the low erosional landforms on the far, Mexican side of the river. Just to the left of this frame rises the massive, fault-scarped rampart of the Sierra del Carmen, famed for its sunset colors, and the great notch of the canyon's mouth. Before venturing in among the cliffs and hoodoos of Lower Cretaceous limestone, we'll take a look at one of this national park's weirdest and most striking plants, a member of a family usually found in wetter, tropical climes. That's next. To see the other photos and descriptions in this set and my other Big Bend series, visit my my Natural History: Big Bend Region & All of Trans-Pecos Texas album.
photos.title: From Persimmon Gap to Boquillas Canyon, Part 8: Reaching Road's End and the River At Last, Big Bend National Park, Texas, USA

photos.description: Taken from a spot between Grave Circle A and the lip of the great wall of Mycenae's citadel (acropolis). Looking southwestward at outer excavations, the site access road, and the parking lot. Beyond lies the valley of the Argos Graben, wrapped in haze. The rectangular-chambered ruin complex in the middle ground is the so-called Oil-Merchant's House Group, sometimes rendered as the Oil-Trader's House instead. It reportedly dates to the 13th century BC, as does much of the works above it. At this range it's difficult to tell if the surviving wall segments were constructed of Mycenae Limestone (Upper Triassic to Middle Jurassic, quarried on surrounding hills) or the Pliocene-to-Pleistocene Mycenae Conglomerate obtained on the floor of the graben below. Probably there's some of both, as is often the case here. There's also a nice cut of limestone-derivedterra rossa soil horizon on the far side of the roadway. To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Mycenaean Magic: Bronze-Age Stonework album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Mycenae, Part 22: Fuori le Mura, or, in the Vulgar, That Which Lies Beyond the Citadel; Peloponnese, Greece

photos.description:
The Palouse River runs through a narrow cataract that drops 61 m (200 ft) into a bowl formed in the canyon which is 115 m (377 ft) deep. Exposing a large cross-section of the Columbia River Basalt Group, the current moves swiftly through a winding gorge of columnar basalt, to its southern end at the mighty Snake River.
Carved more than 13,000 years ago, Palouse Falls is among the last active waterfalls on the Ice Age floods path. At the end of the last ice age, repeated glacial floods known as the Missoula Floods, swept across eastern Washington carving out the unique scablands landscape we see today. 
This natural wonder was named Washington’s state waterfall in 2014, when the state legislature passed a bill written by elementary school students in the nearby town of Washtucna, who had advocated for the designation. It had been dedicated as Palouse Falls State Park on June 3, 1951.
photos.title: Palouse Falls Palouse Falls State Park, Washington
