photos.description: Looking northwestward. This is the church's southern (actually southwestern) elevation, which reportedly retains much of the original building's design and materials. Holy Trinity, the largest of Athenian Byzantine-era churches, has served the city's Russian Orthodox community since its nineteenth-century rehabilitation from its previous ruinous state. As much as I love Date Palms (Phoenix dactylifera) and have extolled their use as street trees on my own native continent—for example, here and here—I dearly wish the tree in the middle of this frame had been planted elsewhere. Still, a fair portion of the characteristic Middle-Byzantine cloisonné masonry is visible nonetheless. A quick check on Google Earth confirms that all the palms have since been removed, though the garden planting at far left has survived. Interestingly, Holy Trinity is essentially a three-quarters-size replica of the much more famous katholikon of the Hosios Loukas Monastery, built not that long before in the wilds of Boeotia. Regarding this church, I'm forced as usual to speculate about the geologic origins of the rough-faced, puckery, and presumably pretty soft ashlar that is set between those typically wafer-thin, double-coursed bricks. Sources I've consulted have much to say about the building's history, but not about the identity of its stone. But the rock does seem to be a dead ringer for poros—the Pliocene-epoch marly and fossiliferous limestone quarried in Megara and Piraeus. Holy Trinity Church is also notable for being dercorated with the kind of pseudo-Kufic symbols so strikingly displayed on the contemporary Holy Apostles Church in the Agora. Unfortunately, it doesn't seem to be visible from this image's vantagepoint. To see the other photos and descriptions in this series, visit my Byzantine and Late Roman Worlds album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Byzantine Athens, Part 6: Holy Trinity Church (early 11th century AD, with a major renovation and rebuilding in the 19th century)

photos.description: Facing westward and looking at the midsection of the Entrance Gate's eastern side. Anyone familiar with the Windy City's iconic Water Tower & Pumping Station will have no trouble identifying this structure's architect—William C. Boyington. That man certainly had a thing for turrets and castellation. And, of course, for Lemont-Joliet Dolostone, the Regional Silurian Dolostone (RSD) variety so widely used in the city's formative decades. Here it's present in rock-faced and regular-to-random-coursed form. Winter is definitely the time to see this fine display of carbonate sedimentary rock at its best, when it's not partially obscured with the foliage of vines that have been permitted to establish such a substantial toehold here. Note the stone's subtly varying weathering tints that give the Lemont-Joliet and other RSD types so much warmth and character. The topographic high on which the cemetery is located is the Rosehill (or Rose Hill) Spit, an elongated, north-south deposit of sand and gravel created by longshore currents approximately 11.5 ka ago, during the Calumet highstand of ancestral Lake Chicago. Originally this landform was dubbed Roe's Hill, after an early property owner. But in the cemetery's charter papers it was mistakenly listed as the phonetically identical Rose Hill, which in latter days has been elided into Rosehill. The fact that the plaque above Entrance Gate's archway uses the modern form of the name makes me think it is of relatively recent date. To learn much more about this site and 200 others in the Windy City, make it your top personal priority to get a copy of my book Chicago in Stone and Clay, described at www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/9781501765063/chicago-i... And to peruse the other photos and descriptions in this series, pay a visit to my Cemetery Science album.
photos.title: Graveyard Geology of Chicago, Part 13: Detail of the Entrance Gate, Rosehill Cemetery, Edgewater Neighborhood (1864)

photos.description:
The main hills are massive, you really have to be here to get the feel of just how large they are. The Painted Hills unit itself is 12.67 km2 (3132 acres)
Averaging about 670 m (2,200 ft) in elevation, the monument has a dry climate with temperatures that vary from summer highs of about 32 °C  (90 °F) to winter lows below freezing. 
The Painted Hills began to form 35 million years ago when pumice and ash from volcanic eruptions in the Cascade Mountains traveled 161km (100 m) east and settled over the area. Once there, the ash and other sediments were mixed by natural processes including the flow of water, growth of plants, and the movement of animals. Over time, this led to oxidation of the ash on the surface. Buried under new layers and deposits, the ash turned into soils by way of compaction and cementation. With more time and weathering, the exterior surfaces of The Painted Hills were worn into clay. Now, they are primarily made of hard claystone layers. A true masterpiece of the ages that continue to tell stories once unknown of the ancient past.

(you can not get close to the 'toes', these images were taken with a long lens)
photos.title: Painted Hills, John Day Fossil Beds National Monument A closer look of the ‘toes’ of the hills Wheeler County, Oregon

photos.description:
This short trail winds through yellow, crimson, and lavender hills, giving you a close view of the incredible popcorn-textured claystone that distinguishes the Painted Hills. 
The colors and hills were formed over 35 million years ago by many volcanic eruptions and changing climate patterns. Layers of ash and soil mixed with mineral and plant matter, coupled with erosion, formed the hills that we see today.
photos.title: Painted Cove Trail  John Day Fossil Beds National Monument Wheeler County, Oregon

photos.description: Facing northeastward. This harmonious blend of brick and stone is one of Frank Lloyd Wright's more famous Prairie Style designs, and it's also one of his most geologically savvy and significant. It demonstrates the imprint of Midwestern stratigraphy on the architect's mind. The flat-lying sedimentary strata of Wright's early stomping grounds, southern Wisconsin and northern Illinois, are elegantly restated here in alternating elements of red St. Louis Brick and buff Salem Limestone. As succeeding photos will show, Wright and his brickmasons took special pains to emphasize the sense of horizontality he'd already seen expressed in the regional outcrops. The St. Louis Brick, iron-flecked and shaped in long, shallow Roman form, was manufactured from the Pennsylvanian (Upper Carboniferous) Cheltenham Clay, an ancient soil horizon in which giant coal-swamp trees once grew. It was mined directly under that great city on the Mississippi. The Salem Limestone, better known to architects as "Bedford Stone" or "Indiana Limestone," is the one most prevalent architectural rock type in the US. Composed of marine-animal fossil fragments naturally cemented together with calcite, it's Mississippian (Lower Carboniferous) in age. For much more on this site and 200 others in the Windy City, see my book Chicago in Stone and Clay, described at www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/9781501765063/chicago-i... And to see the other photos and descriptions of this series, pay a visit to my Geobrickology album.
photos.title: Geobrickology, Part 9: The Frederick C. Robie House, Hyde Park Neighborhood, Chicago, Illinois, USA (1909)

photos.description: Looking northeastward at the facade (western elevation) and a portion of the southern elevation. Even when I visited it in 1978, this former house of worship had been a private residence for almost three-quarters of a century. Nowadays it serves as the Museo Zuloaga. San Juan de los Caballeros was the oldest Romanesque structure I saw when I was in Segovia. However, those conversant with this architectural style will immediately spot one unusual feature here: the great Gothic arch of the entryway. I assume this impressive portal was added at some point after the initial construction; the Gothic mode is usually thought to have originated more than a hundred years after San Juan was raised. But the descriptions of this specific site I've found so far do not address this issue—other to note that that section of the facade also incorporates remains of an earlier Visigothic (6th century) church. In any case, it's evident after checking Google Earth Street View that the building has been at least partially renovated since I photographed it. For one thing, the badly deteriorated ashlar under the blind arches has, I gather, been replaced or reconstituted. My suposition is that it is (or at least was) one of the town's two standard architectural-rock types, the Upper Cretaceous Segovia Sandstone. Looking at the crumbling stonework, it reminds me a lot of other case-hardened sandstone I've seen elsewhere. But, as I keep having to say, provenance is lacking. Another change for the better one can see today is that the wonderful arched porch colonnades that were so indecorously walled up in this image are open again, though the ones in front are now backed by decidedly non-Romanesque glass windows. I wonder if the higher degree of destructive stone weathering I saw at this location was at all linked to San Juan's location, overlooking the north-facing cliff of the city's rocky heights. Or were the masons of the late 11th century just less selective in choosing good-quality sandstone than their 12th- and 13th-century successors? To see the other photos and descriptions in this series, visit my Architectural Geology: Spain album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Segovia, Spain, Part 21: San Juan de los Caballeros Church (late 11th Century AD)

photos.description: Amboy Crater
photos.title: crater
MAREMMA TOSCANA - LA SELVA DEL SASSOFORTE 3228
MAREMMA TOSCANA - LA SELVA DEL SASSOFORTE 3242
MAREMMA TOSCANA - LA SELVA DEL SASSOFORTE 3244

photos.description: Facing southeastward. The porch and main entrance are on the building's western side; also visible is the considerably less altered northern elevation. This vantagepoint may not reveal the full impact of the original cobblestone exterior or the complementing Regional Silurian Dolostone (RSD) quoins the way the Part 13 photo does. But at least it shows the Lannon Dolostone pillars and bay-window base of the 1930s addition to good effect. The Lannon, a RSD variety quarried to this day about 20 mi (32 km) to the southwest of Port Washington, is often extracted in thin-bedded, flaggy sections more suitable for veneer than real ashlar blocks. Most often it is face-mounted in pieces of varying size and shape, in random-course fashion. And so it is here. One of the most attractive aspects of the Lannon—besides its smaller amount of spalling and exfoliation compared to northeastern Illinois' Lemont-Joliet variety—is its polychromatic weathering profile. Some sections retain their original pale-gray color for decades, whereas others turn warmer tones of buff, gold, and even ocher. In the shots that follow we'll focus more fully on the Dodge House's original building materials. To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Geology of Fieldstone & Cobblestone Buildings album.
photos.title: Geology of Fieldstone & Cobblestone Buildings, Part 14: The Edward Dodge House, Port Washington, Wisconsin, USA (1848)

photos.description: Looking northward at the warehouse's southwestern and southeastern elevations. What at first glance may seem an uninteresting, utilitarian structure is in fact one of the Windy City's most delightful expressions of architectural noncontextuality—a concept I'm always willing to admire, praise, and promote. As will become apparent in the photos that follow, the Reebie Warehouse boldly dares to relate to nothing whatsoever around it, and not even to itself. To really appreciate the salutary incongruity present here, you need to lower your gaze to the first story of the building's Clark Street facade. It was there that, at the request of the original owners, designer George S. Kingsley provided something rarely seen in storage warehouses, at least since the Ptolemaic Dynasty: a whopping dose of Ancient Egyptian design motifs. This remarkable Roaring-Twenties riff on pharaonic magnificence, breathtaking in its cognitive dissonance, was executed in polychrome terra-cotta crafted twenty blocks to the west, in Chicago's Northwestern works. Northwestern's base material was derived from Pennsylvanian-subperiod (Upper Carboniferous) underclays and marine shales unearthed in the bituminous-coal mines of the Illinois Basin, and then shipped up to the big city by rail. The pictures that follow will concentrate, at considerably closer range, on the wonderful terra-cotta cladding that was produced from this 300-Ma-old material. For more on this site, see my book Chicago in Stone and Clay, described at www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/9781501765063/chicago-i... To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Terra-Cottalogy album.
photos.title: The Geology of Terra-Cotta, Part 10: The Reebie Storage Warehouse, Lincoln Park Neighborhood, Chicago, Illinois, USA (1922)

photos.description: This shot, taken at the spring freshet, shows at closer range the same section of the rear wall seen in the Part 2 photo. This is quite a complicated patchwork of shade and sunlight and contrasting colors, all seen through a curtain of water droplets falling from the cliff edge above. Still, the strata of the thin-bedded Pounds Sandstone are perfectly visible with their well-preserved crossbedding. The Pounds, a member of the Lower Pennsylvanian (early Upper Carboniferous) Caseyville Formation, was deposited by streams like the Bell Smith Springs canyon's own modern-day Bay Creek. In other words, they too were incised into older bedrock. And the left-to-right direction of their flow is indicated by the slanting crossbeds. For more on this beautiful and geologically fascinating locale, get a copy of my Geology Underfoot in Illinois. And to see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Natural History: Illinois album.
photos.title: The Bounty of Bell Smith Springs, Part 3: Close-Up of the Cliff Wall behind the Natural Bridge, Bell Smith Springs, Shawnee National Forest, Illinois, USA

photos.description: This detail of the Amphitheater's interior focuses on both the Ancient Roman Brick facing and the Ancient Roman Concrete exposed above and below it. The latter building material is so alien to our modern conception of concrete—the smooth-textured Ready Mix stuff that's poured out of a truck and forms something pretty reminiscent of compact, slightly sandy limestone—that we think of it as stonemasonry instead. And here it does appear to be about 1 part lime-pozzolana mortar to 9 parts cobbles (or brick fragments or broken tiles, or whatever the exact roster of aggregrate ingedients is in this case). But how well it worked. When I think of all the less-than-a-century-old concrete structures in my own country that are in bad need of repair, I have all the more respect for Imperial builders and architects who accomplished so much with such rudimentary technology, and with so little formal understanding of chemistry and materials science. For more on the Colosseum's geology and geoengineering, see the other photos and descriptions of this series in my Architectural Geology: Italy album.
photos.title: Colosseum Geology 101, Part 5: The Flavian Amphitheater, Rome, Italy (AD 80)

photos.description: Taken facing east. My razor-sharp directional sense thereby deduces that we're looking at the building's western elevation. In my humble opinion, one of the greatest glories of American architecture is found far from its biggest cities, in its nineteenth-century rural county courthouses. And if they happen to be constructed in the Richardsonian Romanesque style, as here, so much the better. These distinctive structures are the incarnation of local civic pride in the last places in this country where democracy still works. Everything about them hearkens back to a very different world. In fact, they're miniature worlds in themselves. Their ceiling-fanned, oak-paneled hallways and clerks' offices are populated with warmhearted people named Vern and Darlene, and tend to give off a composite scent of Lysol, prairie soil, floor wax, and legal documents aged like fine wine in century-old filing cabinets. There's so much to explore, inside and out. What's visible here is an especially impressive array of building materials, all obtained, in an admirable display of Badger State solidarity, from Wisconsin sources. The Green County Courthouse and adjoining Civil War Monument—there always has to be an adjoining Civil War Monument—are so geologically rich that I'm going to devote several posts to them. At least several. The most striking component of the exterior is that luridly lovely red brick. It could easily pass for a premium-grade Philadelphia facing variety, but according to local documents it actually hails from the Upper-Mississippi-Valley hamlet of Maiden Rock, about 250 road mi (402 km) northwest of Monroe. Whether its clay was mined from Quaternary deposits laid down by the Father of the Waters, I don't know. This production locality was not cited in any publications on Wisconsin brickmaking I've come across so far. The contrasting yellowish-buff, rock-faced ashlar is described in my sources simply as "limestone." But it's actually dolostone. For reasons I'll discuss in future photo descriptions, I don't think it's the locally quarried Plattevile-Galena rock of Ordovician age, but rather reefal Regional Silurian Dolostone from Wauwatosa or some other place in the eastern section of the state. Also on display, if just barely, is the ruddy and almost supernaturally hard Montello Granite in the shafts of the porch pillars. It formed as part of magma emplacement connected with a megavolcanic eruption event in the Paleoproterozoic. But more on that anon. To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit Architectural Geology: Southwestern Wisconsin album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Southwestern Wisconsin, Part 9: Green County Courthouse, Monroe, Wisconsin, USA (1891)

photos.description: Taken in what was then the roofless shell of the Palace. I believe we're facing the junction of the western and southern walls, but after all these years I can't be sure. The heavy growth of moss or some other type of vegetation on the vertical surfaces makes the pattern of masonry quite indistinct in places. But a little scrutiny reveals that there's the same alternation of Miocene-epoch Bakırköy Limestone with horizontal bands of red brick seen in Part 3. None of the free-range fowl who followed me into the ruined building are visible in this shot, but they'll make their appearance in a later image. I'd like to think they were inspired by my own geological and architectural curiosity. But they, being true to their chicken-brained nature, probably just thought I was there to feed them. Some of the upper window arches clearly show the decorative effect of stone alternating with thick-mortared bricks. There also seem to be some much more recently added stone or concrete blocks farther down. They are of a much more uniform shape than the rest of the ashlar. To see the other photos and descriptions in this series, visit my Architectural Geology: Turkey album.
photos.title: A Marvel of Masonry, Part 4: The Palace of the Porphyrogenitus (late 13th Century) and the Blachernae Walls (different sections in different centuries), Istanbul, Turkey
Sharm el Sheikh

photos.description: Facing northeastward and toward the cathedral's facade (western elevation) and southern elevation. This handsome Neo-Byzantine edifice is one of the most striking and effective twentieth-century expressions of Regional Silurian Dolostone (RSD) I've seen. Geologically speaking, St. Sava is particularly distinctive because it's clad not in the usual latter-day RSD selection, Lannon Dolostone, but in very similar rock quarried about 40 mi (65 km) farther north, on the southern outskirts of Fond du Lac, Wisconsin. The Fond du Lac Dolostone on display here is a subtly varicolored rock type that, like the Lannon, is shown to its best effect as random-coursed, rock-faced cladding. In addition, the church exterior features portal elements, trim, and window surrounds of light-gray Salem ("Bedford," "Indiana") Limestone. This Mississippian-subperiod (Lower Carboniferous) biocalcarenite is often used as a blander and much more carvable complement to RSD varieties. Also notice the copper roofs of the domes, nave, and transepts. In the course of fifty-five years, they've reach their metal's end-state of weathering—the bluish-green patina characteristic of copper sulfate and copper carbonate compounds. This site, and many others in Milwaukee County, will be discussed at greater length in my forthcoming book Milwaukee in Stone and Clay (NIU Imprint of Cornell University Press, scheduled for release in early 2024). Stay tuned! And you'll find the other photos and descriptions of this series in my Glory of Silurian Dolostone album.
photos.title: The Glory of Regional Silurian Dolostone, Part 27: St. Sava Serbian Orthodox Cathedral, Lyons Park Neighborhood, Milwaukee, Wisconsin, USA (1958)

photos.description: Taken along the western side of Rio Grande Village Road, about 0.2 road mi (0.4 km) northeast of the big Tornillo Creek Bridge. This vantagepoint is a few tens of meters/yards northeast of the Part 6 photo. I arrived at this site none too soon. A few minutes later the shadow evident at bottom had obscured even the crest of this rise. As it was, though, the low-angle light of late afternoon beautifully highlighted the dike of igneous rock cutting through Upper Cretaceous Pen Formation shale and claystone. The Pen beds closest to the dike were cooked into somewhat harder form when the magma forced its way into them. This is a very localized version of what geologists call contact metamorphism. Also getting its last dose of direct sun is a scraggily cluster of what I suppose is Faxon Yucca (Yucca faxoniana). This species is better known in Trans-Pecos Texas as Dagger—a fitting tribute to its lethally pointed, rigid, and sword-shaped leaves. As you can see for yourself on Google Earth, in both aerial and street views, the dike actually runs straight as an arrow on both sides of the road. But, as noted in the previous description, I can find no source that identifies its exact petrologic composition. To see the other photos and descriptions in this set and my other Big Bend series, visit my my Natural History: Big Bend Region & All of Trans-Pecos Texas album.
photos.title: From Persimmon Gap to Boquillas Canyon, Part 7: As the Shadows Fall, Big Bend National Park, Texas, USA

photos.description: Facing one of the shaft-grave walls in this famous burial complex. While the unmortared rubble blocks on view in this shot are probably too small to be considered cyclopean—the help of a mythical one-eyed giant wouldn't have been required to heft them—they are just about as diverse in shape as they are monolithic in the type of stone they represent. The fact that the larger chunks of rock are being held in place by so many wedgelike smaller ones makes me wonder whether this wall was largely rebuilt in the nineteenth century AD or later by archaeological excavators. I have trouble imagining all those tidy little bits surviving in their appointed nooks since the Late Bronze Age. However recent or ancient this particular masonry is, the material it's made of, the locally quarried Mycenae Limestone, has a history that stretches back more than 200 Ma. It was in the span from the Upper Triassic to the Middle Jurassic periods of the Mesozoic era that this sedimentary rock began as limey mud deposited on a carbonate platform in the Tethys Ocean. At that time, that great saltwater seaway stretched all the way from Spain to what is now Southeast Asia. To see the other photos and descriptions of this series, visit my Mycenaean Magic: Bronze-Age Stonework album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Mycenae, Part 21: Close-Up of Limestone Masonry, Grave Circle A, Peloponnese, Greece

photos.description: Looking west-southwestward at the church's eastern elevation. I'm not sure what sort of repair or restoration work was underway during my visit, but I am sure that nothing would have tempted me to walk up that ramshackle timber ramp. One of the distinctive design features of Sts. Theodores is that has three triple-sided apses. I would love to think there was some doubling down on Trinitarian symbolism going on here, but I may just be playing too much into it. In any event, this vantagepoint offers a great view both of the pitted "poros" ashlar—probably either Piraeus Limestone or Megara Limestone, both of which are marly, highly fossiliferous, and Pliocene—and the brick-and-stone cloisonné masonry so typical of Athenian Middle Byzantine style. In this shot, the terra-cotta solenes and kalupter tiles look pretty mossy and patched in places with some whitish material (concrete?). Much more modern imagery on Google Earth Street View shows the roof in better shape overall. Also note the striking brick-and-thick-mortar patterns adorning the upper reaches of the arched windows. To see the other photos and descriptions in this series, visit my Byzantine and Late Roman Worlds album.
photos.title: Architectural Geology of Byzantine Athens, Part 5: Pardon Our Dust at Sts. Theodores Church (ca. mid-11th century AD)
